bioghist.p: Archibald Roy Crouch (b. 1909) received his B.Th. from Princeton Theological Seminary in 1933. He also received a master's degree from Corness University and a Ph.D. in sociology from the University of Southern California. He was Pastor in churches in California and Minnesota and began Missionary work in China in 1936. He taught English in Ningpo and performed emergency war work there, 1938 and 1939-1941. He also taught English in Shanghai from 1938 to 1939. In 1946 he returned to the United States, where he helped raise the Restoration Fund of the Presbyterian Church, and organize the National Council of Presbyterian Men along the Pacific Coast. Crouch was also Secretary for Communications of the COEMAR of the UPCUSA. From 1950 to 1952 he was director of the Westminster Foundation at the University of California in Berkeley. He published weekly columns in The Cambrian and The Morro Bay Sun.

scopecontent.p: This collection includes labor activity reports written in Crouch's capacity as a missionary. Activity reports include lists of meetings and speaking engagements; summary statistics of meeting attendance; and staff hours and financial statements, 1942-1969. There are reports of the Furlough Fellowship, 1942-1947; the National Council of Presbyterian Men, 1949-1950; Westminster Foundation, 1950-1952; the Western Area Office (of which Crouch was Secretary) of the Commission on Ecumenical Mission and Relations (COEMAR), 1952-1960; and from the communications office of COEMAR, 1961-1969. The collection also includes a number of academic articles by Crouch on various topics related to his work in China and Chinese history, philosophy, and religion (1940s-1980s). These include guides to China mission resources in archives and libraries in Pennsylvania and the United States, and "Dragon Scales," a series of Crouch's radio talks on China, aired in 1941-1944. There are also pamphlets and printed materials on Chinese history, politics, and religion; newsletters; a scrapbook related to his work in China, including clippings, correspondence, and photographs; and a scrapbook of clippings of Crouch's "Ricksha Rambles" column, published in The Cambrian (Cambria Pines, California), 1937-1941 and 1944-1946.
